If a practitioner wishes to seek the concentration on space, they should think like this:
Form is the various tools of suffering, such as whips, sticks, cutting, killing, hunger, cold, old age, illness, and other sufferings, all due to form.
Contemplating in this way, one abandons form and attains the sphere of space.
Question:
Since the practitioner now takes form as their body, how can they then abandon it?
Answer:
The afflictions are the causes of form and can also bind form. The cessation of these afflictions is called the abandonment of form.
Furthermore, practicing the method of contemplating the emptiness of the destruction of form leads to the abandonment of form.

Furthermore, as the Buddha said, a bhiká¹£u observes the five aggregates of the fourth dhyÄna as a disease, a boil, a thorn, impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self. Such observations are detachments from the five aggregates of the fourth dhyÄna. Since the remaining aggregates follow form, it is said to only detach from form.
Why is it so?
Because form is ultimately exhausted.

Furthermore, the practitioner observes form, breaking it down into parts, and there is no form. Just as the body has parts, the head, feet, shoulders, arms, etc., each with different parts, there is no body;
Just as the head has the parts of eyes, ears, nose, tongue, mouth, beard, hair, bones, flesh, etc., dividing them into different parts, there is no head;

Just as the eye, the combination of the four great elements, the four sense bases, the body faculty, and the eye faculty, the ten things, the white and black parts, etc., the mass of flesh is called the eye. If each is distinguished, there is no eye. The parts such as earth, etc., are also like this.
Question:
The four great elements that form the eye faculty cannot be determined as form. How can it be distinguished?
Answer:
The four great elements and the pure form created by the four great elements are combined and called the eye. If this form is removed, there is no eye.
Moreover, although this pure form is invisible, it has resistance and therefore has parts. Because it has parts, there is no eye.
Furthermore, that which can see form is called the eye.
If the four great elements and the form created by the four great elements are removed, there is no eye.
If there is no eye that can see form, the ear should also be the eye.
If the eye is a form, all forms have a place and parts, so they should be distinguishable. If they are distinguishable, there would be many eyes.
If it is said that the eye is made of the many subtle particles created by the four great elements, it should not be a single eye;
if it is not an eye at all, there is also no single eye.
If it is said that the subtle particles are the eye, this is also not so.
Why is it so?
If the subtle particle has form, it has the ten directions and is not called a subtle particle;
if it is not form, it is not called an eye.
Furthermore, the substance of a particle definitely has four parts:
color, smell, taste, and touch. The eye is not these four things.
Why is it so?
Because the eye is categorized as an internal sense base, while the four are categorized as external sense bases. For this reason, one cannot take the various particles as the eye.
As the Buddha said, the seeing of form through the combination of various factors is provisionally called the eye. There is no definite reality.
The ear, nose, tongue, skin, flesh, bones, etc. are also like this in being refuted.
This is the refutation of the characteristics of the internal body.
External forms, palaces, wealth, wives, children, etc. are also all like this in being analyzed and refuted.
As the Buddha told Ratthapala:
From today onwards, you should shatter and disperse form, destroy form, and make it formless.
Being able to analyze in this way is called being apart from form.

Furthermore, as the Buddha said, if a bhiká¹£u wishes to be apart from form, transcend all characteristics of form, extinguish all characteristics of resistance, and not think of all different characteristics, he enters the stage of infinite space.
Transcending all forms refers to visible forms;
Destroying all opposing characteristics refers to imperceptible forms that are resistant;
Not thinking of any different characteristics refers to imperceptible forms that are non-resistant.
Furthermore, transcending all forms refers to various forms such as blue, yellow, red, white, and purple;
Destroying the resistant refers to sound, smell, taste, and touch;
Not thinking of any different characteristics refers to size, length, short, square, round, far, and near, etc.
Thus, by being apart from all forms, one can enter the sphere of space.

Furthermore, the practitioner focuses the mind on the internal empty space of the body, namely the mouth, nose, throat, eyes, ears, chest, abdomen, etc. Knowing that form is a multitude of afflictions, and emptiness is free from troubles, the mind thus delights in emptiness. If the mind is in form, it is restrained and placed in emptiness. The mind becomes more pliable, causing the empty space in the body to gradually expand. One sees one's physical body like a hole in a lotus root. As practice becomes more advanced, one sees the body as entirely empty, without any form.
External forms are also like this.

The internal and external emptiness are unified as a single emptiness. At this time, the mind contemplates emptiness as immeasurable and boundless, and one then becomes free from the notion of form, peaceful and blissful. It is like a bird in a bottle. When the bottle is broken, it can soar in the sky without obstruction. This is called the first formless concentration.

The practitioner regards the feelings, perceptions, mental formations, and consciousness in emptiness as a disease, a boil, a wound, a thorn, impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self. Seeking a more wonderful concentration, one then becomes free from the condition of emptiness.
Why is this so?
Knowing that this is a mental state, that the thought of space is deceptive and false, that it did not exist before but now exists, and that after existing it will again not exist.
Having known its faults, this space arises from consciousness, and consciousness is considered true.

But only observing consciousness and abandoning the condition of space, when practicing the observation of consciousness, one gradually sees the characteristics of consciousness arising in continuity, like a flowing stream or a burning flame. Future, present, and past consciousness, the continuity of consciousness is boundless and immeasurable.
Question:
Why did the Buddha say that the sphere of consciousness is boundless and immeasurable?
Answer:
Because consciousness can reach far, it is boundless. Because it conditions boundless dharmas, it is boundless.

Furthermore, previously conditioning boundless space, if one destroys boundless space, consciousness should be boundless. Because the practitioner's mind is flexible, it can make consciousness great and even boundless. This is called the sphere of boundless consciousness.
Question:
This sphere of consciousness is fully endowed with the four aggregates. Why is it only called the sphere of consciousness?
Answer:
In all internal dharmas, consciousness is the main factor, and all mental factors are subordinate to consciousness. If one speaks of consciousness, then one speaks of the other matters.

Furthermore, in the desire realm, the form aggregate is the main factor. In the form realm, the feeling aggregate is the main factor. In the sphere of infinite space and the sphere of infinite consciousness, the consciousness aggregate is the main factor. In the sphere of nothingness, the perception aggregate is the main factor. In the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, the formation aggregate is the main factor.
Furthermore, there are three dharmas:
body, mind, and mental factors.
In the desire realm and the form realm, the body is the main factor, because the mind follows the body. If there is no body, the power of the mind alone is used.
The mind has two aspects:
one aspect is directed towards emptiness, and one aspect is directed towards itself. Therefore, there should be two spheres:
the sphere of infinite space and the sphere of infinite consciousness.
But because the form is initially destroyed, emptiness receives the name. Because emptiness is destroyed, consciousness alone is named.
Mental factors also have two aspects:
one aspect is perception, and one aspect is formation. Therefore, there should also be two spheres:
The thought of the sphere of nothingness leads to the practice of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
Furthermore, by relying on consciousness one can depart from the sphere of space. For this reason, although there are other aggregates, only consciousness is named.
The practitioner, having attained the sphere of consciousness, further seeks for a wonderful concentration. He observes consciousness as a calamity, as explained above.

Furthermore, he observes consciousness as illusory and deceptive, belonging to various causes and conditions, and not being independent. When there are conditions, it arises; when there are no conditions, it ceases. Consciousness does not abide in the mind, nor does it abide in conditions, nor does it abide in between. It does not have a place to abide, nor does it not have a place to abide. The characteristics of consciousness are like this.
The World-Honored One said:
Consciousness is like an illusion.
The practitioner, having contemplated in this way, can depart from the sphere of consciousness.
Furthermore, the practitioner thinks like this: Just as the five desires are false and deceptive, so is form.ğŸ”½Just as form is false and deceptive, so is space.
Just as space is false and deceptive, so are the characteristics of consciousness.

All of these are false and deceptive, yet sentient beings are deluded and attached, thinking that the emptiness and non-existence of all phenomena is a state of peace and security. Having had this thought, they then enter the sphere of nothingness.
Question:
What is the difference between the sphere of space and the sphere of nothingness?
Answer:
In the former, the mind contemplates space as the condition, while in the latter, the mind contemplates nothingness as the condition. This is the difference.

After the practitioner has entered the sphere of nothingness, those with sharp faculties realize that within it there are still feelings, perceptions, mental formations, and consciousness to be disgusted with, as explained before;
those with dull faculties are unable to realize this.
Furthermore, there are three views for abandoning the sphere of nothingness:
the view of existence, the view of non-existence, and the view of neither existence nor non-existence.
The view of existence extends from the desire realm up to the sphere of consciousness;
the view of non-existence is precisely the sphere of nothingness;
the view of neither existence nor non-existence is the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.
This view of non-existence should be abandoned.
Why is this?

Although the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception is subtle, it should still be abandoned, let alone the sphere of nothingness. Having had this thought, one leaves the sphere of nothingness.
Question:
In the Buddha's teachings, there is also emptiness and nothingness. If this is true, why is it said that wrong views should be abandoned?
Answer:
In the Buddha's teachings, it is used to break attachments, so it is not considered real;
The sphere of nothingness is considered real, and because of wrong views and attachment,

The beings there experience the retribution of the meditative state, and then according to the causes and conditions of their karma, they experience various retributions. For this reason, it should be abandoned.
Although the names are similar, they are actually different.
Furthermore, the practitioner thinks like this:

All stages with conceptualization are coarse and afflictive, like illness, like a boil, like a wound, like an arrow. The stage of non-conceptualization is a state of delusion. Now, the most subtle and supreme state is the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.
Having contemplated in this way, one then departs from the stage of the conception of the sphere of nothingness and enters the sphere of neither conception nor non-conception.
Question:
Is there conception or no conception in this [sphere]?
Answer:
There is conception in this [sphere].
Question:
If there is conception, why are only the lower seven stages called the sphere of conception?
Answer:
In this stage, conception is subtle and not sharp, and the function of conception is not clear, so it is not called conception.

The practitioner's mind regards this [sphere] as neither conception nor non-conception, and therefore the Buddha follows its original name and calls it the sphere of neither conception nor non-conception.

Those of dull faculties do not realize that there are four aggregates in this [sphere], and they regard it as the peaceful abode of nirvana, giving rise to a sense of superiority, with a lifespan of 80,000 kalpas before falling back into the various destinies.
Although the four aggregates in this [sphere] are subtle, profound, and wonderful, those of sharp faculties are able to realize this. Having realized it, they become weary and think:

This is also a compounded dharma, an arisen dharma from causes and conditions, false and unreal, like a disease, like a boil, like a wound, like an arrow, impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self. It is also a cause for subsequent birth. One should abandon it because of its faults and study the four truths.
Question:
When abandoning the other stages, why is it not said to study the four truths?
Answer:

Previously it was said to be like a disease, like a boil, like a wound, like an arrow, impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self, which is a brief explanation of the four truths, but it was not yet explained in detail.
Furthermore, the other stages have no prohibitions and no difficulties, because ordinary beings can also transcend them using contaminated paths.
However, this peak of existence can only be transcended by noble ones who study the uncontaminated path.
It is like a bird whose leg is tied with a rope. Although it can initially fly away, the rope pulls it back.
Ordinary beings are also like this. Although they transcend the other stages, the demon king is not alarmed by it;
If one transcends the realm above the peak of existence, the great demon king will be greatly startled, like a rope breaking and a bird flying away.
For this reason, when leaving other realms, the four truths are not mentioned.
The realm above the peak of existence is the essential gate of the three realms. In order to leave the essential gate, one should study the four truths.
Question:
What are the four truths?
Answer:
The truth of suffering, the truth of the cause of suffering, the truth of the cessation of suffering, and the truth of the path.
There are two kinds of suffering:
First, physical suffering; second, mental suffering.
There are also two kinds of the cause of suffering:
First, afflictions; second, entanglements.
There are also two kinds of cessation:
First, nirvana with remainder; second, nirvana without remainder.
There are also two kinds of the path:
First, concentration; second, wisdom.
Furthermore, there are two kinds of the truth of suffering:
First, the truth of suffering; second, the noble truth of suffering.
The truth of suffering is characterized by affliction, namely the five aggregates of clinging are called the truth of suffering.
The noble truth of suffering is the path cultivated due to knowledge and insight, which is called the noble truth of suffering.
The truth of accumulation is of two kinds.
One is the truth of accumulation, and the other is the noble truth of accumulation.
The truth of accumulation refers to the characteristic of origination, namely the afflictions such as craving, which are called the truth of accumulation.
The noble truth of accumulation is the path cultivated due to elimination, which is the noble truth of accumulation.
The truth of cessation is of two kinds:
One is the truth of cessation, and the other is the noble truth of cessation.
The truth of cessation refers to the characteristic of quiescence, namely the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a, which is called the truth of cessation.
The noble truth of cessation is the path practiced due to realization, which is the noble truth of cessation.
The truth of the path is of two kinds:
One is the truth of the path, and the other is the noble truth of the path.
The truth of the path refers to the characteristic of going out and reaching, namely the eightfold noble path, which is called the truth of the path.
The noble truth of the path is the path practiced due to cultivation, which is the noble truth of the path.
Furthermore, there are two kinds of truths:
General characteristics and specific characteristics.
The general characteristic of suffering is the five aggregates;
The specific characteristic of suffering is the extensive classification of the form aggregate, feeling aggregate, perception aggregate, mental formation aggregate, and consciousness aggregate.
The general characteristic of the cause of suffering is that which gives rise to the experience of the subsequent body;

The specific characteristic of the cause of suffering is the extensive classification of the causes and conditions of the five aggregates, such as craving and other afflictions and contaminated actions.
The general characteristic of the cessation of suffering is the exhaustion of craving that gives rise to the subsequent body;
The specific characteristic of the cessation of suffering is the extensive classification of the eighty-nine types of exhaustion.
The general characteristic of the path is the eightfold noble path;
The specific characteristic of the path is the extensive classification from the acceptance of the truth of suffering up to the path of no-more-learning.
If one does not penetrate the four truths, then one will revolve in the five destinies, coming and going in birth and death without a time of rest.

For this reason, the practitioner should contemplate that all suffering and distress, such as old age, sickness, and death, are all due to having a body, just as all grasses and trees come forth from the earth.
As it is said in the scriptures, the reason sentient beings in the ten directions have bodies is all because of suffering.
It is like poisonous food, whether good or ugly, all can kill people;
If there is no body or mind, then suffering and death have no place to rely on.
It is like a violent wind uprooting a large tree, if there is no tree, then there is nothing to destroy.

Thus, in brief, the body and mind are the basis for experiencing suffering, like the basis of wind in space, wood is the basis of fire, earth is the basis of water, and the body is the basis of suffering.

Moreover, just as earth is always characterized by solidity, water is always characterized by wetness, fire is always characterized by heat, and wind is always characterized by movement, the body and mind are always characterized by suffering.
Why is this so?
Because of having a body, then the suffering of old age, sickness, death, hunger, thirst, cold, heat, wind, rain, and so forth always follow it;
Because of having a mind, then the suffering of worry, fear, anger, jealousy, and so forth always follow it.
If one knows that the present body is painful, the past pain is also like this. As the present and past body is painful, the future is also like this.
It is like seeing that the present grain seed produces grain, inferring that the past and future are also all like this.
Also, like the present fire's characteristic of heat, inferring that the past and future fire is also hot.
In this way, if there is no body or mind, there was no pain before, there is no pain now, and there will be no pain later.
One should know that the pain of the three periods of time all comes from the body and mind. Therefore, one should contemplate the truth of suffering.

In this way, the mind gives rise to disgust. The causes and conditions of suffering only arise from afflictions such as craving, not from heaven, time, nature, or without causes and conditions. If one is apart from afflictions, then there is no arising.

One should know that the world all arises from afflictions such as craving, just as when a person creates things, desire is always foremost. Therefore, afflictions are the causes and conditions of suffering.

Furthermore, one receives a body due to the water of craving. If there were no water of craving, one would not receive a body. It is like dry soil that cannot stick to a wall, but when water is added, it sticks.

Furthermore, because of the various afflictions, one receives a body with various differences. It is like those with much desire receiving a body with much desire, those with much anger receiving a body with much anger, those with much delusion receiving a body with much delusion, and those with thin afflictions receiving a body with thin afflictions. Because the present retribution is seen to be different, it is known that the past causes and conditions are each separate. The differences in receiving bodies in the future according to the afflictions are also like this. Receiving bodies according to karma is also like this.
If one is not angry, one will not receive the form of a poisonous snake. All other forms are also like this.

Therefore, one should know that love and other afflictions are the causes and conditions of all suffering. When the causes and conditions of suffering are exhausted, there is the cessation of suffering and nirvana. Nirvana is called the cessation of desire, the severing of all afflictions and eternal non-change. In it there is no birth, no aging, no sickness, no death, no suffering of separation from what is loved, no suffering of being with what is hated, and it is eternally blissful and never regresses.
When the practitioner attains nirvana and liberation, there is nowhere to go, and it is called quiescence.
It is like a burning lamp: when the oil is exhausted, it goes out and does not reach any direction. This is called the truth of cessation.

The means of attaining nirvana are the path of concentration, which is divided into three aspects, the path of wisdom, which is divided into two aspects, and the path of precepts, which is also divided into three aspects. Abiding in these precepts, one cultivates concentration and wisdom.
That is to say, wisdom that can discern the four truths is called right view.
Following right view, arousing the Dharma, is called right thought.
These are called the two aspects of wisdom.
Right concentration, right mindfulness, and right effort are called the three kinds of concentration factors.
Right speech, right action, and right livelihood are called the three kinds of precepts.

By abiding in pure precepts, the sprouts of afflictions are not allowed to grow, and their power weakens, like seeds planted out of season whose sprouts do not grow. When the power of afflictions comes, the concentration factors can block them, like a great mountain damming water, which the water cannot break through.
It is like a spell that can restrain a poisonous snake, so that although it still has poison, it cannot harm people. The concentration factors are also like this.
Wisdom can uproot the fundamental afflictions, like the swollen waters of summer that carry away all the trees on the banks.
Practicing these three parts of the eightfold path, which is the true, straight, and correct way, can extinguish the causes of suffering and ultimately bring peace, constant bliss, and non-action.
If one initially practices the methods skillfully, there are ten things:
First, the mind is focused and upright. Various external matters may come to disturb it, but it cannot be moved, like a mountain unshaken by winds from the four directions.

Second, being straightforward, one hears the teacher's teachings without seeing their length or brevity, the mind without increase or decrease follows the teachings without doubt, like entering a dense forest to gather wood, the straight one comes out easily while the crooked one comes out with difficulty. Thus, in the dense forest of the three realms, the straight one comes out easily while the crooked one comes out with difficulty. In the Buddha's teachings, only the straight one is used, while the crooked one is discarded.

Third, having a sense of shame and modesty is the foremost garment, the most wonderful adornment. The hook of shame and modesty restrains the evil mind. Having a sense of shame and modesty truly makes one a person. If one lacks a sense of shame and modesty, one is no different from an animal.

Fourth, being vigilant means that it is the root of all wholesome dharmas. Just as in the world, being negligent leads to losing all beneficial matters, practitioners being negligent lose the benefit of nirvana. One should know that being negligent is like an enemy or a thief, and the mind should always be far away from it. One should know that being vigilant is like a ruler, father, or teacher, and one should follow and not abandon it.

Fifth, being secluded means that based on this seclusion, one becomes vigilant. If one is close to the five desires, the faculties will develop. First, the body is always separated from the village, and next, the mind is secluded and does not think of worldly matters.
Sixth, having few desires means that one does not seek many things for one's livelihood, because seeking much leads to falling into various troubles.
Seventh, being content means that even if one has few desires, if one enjoys and clings to fine things, it will ruin one's resolve. Therefore, the wise one only seeks to be content.

Eighth, the mind should not be attached. If disciples, donors, acquaintances, or relatives come to greet and send off, and there are many things to do, such things will ruin the path, so one should not be attached to them.
Ninth, they do not enjoy worldly pleasures, such as singing, dancing, music, choosing auspicious days and times, or any worldly affairs.
Tenth, they are patient. When practitioners seek the Way, they should endure ten things:

First, mosquitoes and gadflies harming them, second, poisonous snakes biting them, third, poisonous beasts, fourth, scolding and slander, fifth, being beaten and harmed, sixth, illness and pain, seventh, hunger, eighth, thirst, ninth, cold, and tenth, heat. Practitioners endure such afflictions and do not let them overcome them, always overcoming these things.

Furthermore, it is like a person who knows the symptoms of illness, knows the causes of illness, knows the medicine for curing illness, and has a caregiver. If they get what they need, they will soon recover.

Practitioners are like this. They know the true characteristics of suffering, know the causes of suffering, know the path to the end of suffering, know how to get a good teacher and fellow students, and in this way, they will soon attain peace and tranquility.
Question:

Having attained the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and entered deep meditation, only the afflictions of the upper realms are slightly thin, and the mind has already become pliable. It is not appropriate to contemplate these four truths with various causes and conditions and various parables, as if one does not believe?
Answer:

It is not only for those of the peak of existence, but in general for all those of the peak of existence. One only contemplates the impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self of the four aggregates of the formless realm, like a disease, like a wound, like an arrow piercing the heart. Impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self are all conditioned by causes and conditions, and one contemplates nirvana as supreme, wonderful, peaceful, and blissful, not as a conditioned dharma that is real and not false. One extinguishes the three poisons and three afflictions, and the suffering of body and mind ceases. Constantly criticizing the four aggregates and their causes and conditions is called the truth of suffering and the truth of accumulation. Praising nirvana and the path to nirvana is called the truth of cessation and the truth of the path.

Practitioners who have attained the four dhyÄnas and four formless concentrations have already softened their minds. If they seek the five supernatural powers, it is easy to attain them based on the fourth dhyÄna. If they rely on the first, second, or third dhyÄnas, although they can attain them, it is very difficult to seek them, and even if attained, they are not firm.
Why is this?

Because the first dhyÄna is disturbed by initial and sustained thought, the second dhyÄna has much joy, and the third dhyÄna has much bliss, which are contrary to concentration. The four bases of supernatural power are all characteristics of concentration. Only in the fourth dhyÄna is there neither suffering nor bliss, neither sorrow nor joy, and neither inhalation nor exhalation. It is where sages dwell in happiness and peace. Therefore, practitioners should rely on the fourth dhyÄna to cultivate the four bases of supernatural power.

Namely, the method of accomplishing the supernatural power of concentration through desire, the method of accomplishing the supernatural power of concentration through effort, the method of accomplishing the supernatural power of concentration through mind, and the method of accomplishing the supernatural power of concentration through contemplation. Relying on this, there is nothing that cannot be attained.
Question:
How does one accomplish the supernatural power of concentration through desire?
Answer:

Desire is the desire for the sought-after matter. Concentration is the single-pointed mind without increase or decrease. The practice of the Dharma refers to faith, mindfulness, skillful wisdom, joy, pleasure, and other factors that assist in achieving desire and concentration. Because concentration is attained by taking desire as the dominant factor, it is called desire-concentration;
The same is true for vigor-concentration, mind-concentration, and contemplation-concentration.

The practitioner observes desire, not allowing it to have increase or decrease, not allowing too much internal absorption or external dispersion. It should be soft, balanced, harmonious, and workable, just like playing the zither, adjusting its looseness and tightness, and then playing any tune.
Vigor, mind, and contemplation are also like this. It is like a practitioner learning to fly. The desire to fly is called desire;
Gathering and assisting the practice of the Dharma, this is called vigor and mind;

Being able to lift the body and mind away from physical and mental heaviness, sleepiness, agitation, and so forth, the mind becomes light and agile. Because the mind is light, it can lift the body. This is called mind;
Measuring the amount of desire and diligence in the mind, one can lift the body but cannot destroy the internal and external forms and flavors, this is called contemplation.
Relying on the four bases of supernatural power, one can fully possess all merits, let alone the five supernatural powers!
Question:
Which of the five supernatural powers arises first?
Answer:
It is the one that is most enjoyed that comes first.
Question:
If so, why is the supernatural power of transformation mentioned first?
Answer:
The five supernatural powers are mostly for the sake of sentient beings.
Why is this so?
Like an arhat liberated by wisdom, having attained arhatship, he thinks like this:

There are many sentient beings with dull faculties who do not believe in the Buddha's teachings and slight the Dharma. I have attained the difficult matter of exhausting the defilements and possessing supernatural powers. How can I not manifest supernatural powers to teach and transform sentient beings and cause them to fall into offenses?
Moreover, the Buddha's great compassion benefits sentient beings. I am the Buddha's disciple and should assist sentient beings with supernatural powers.

However, sentient beings often benefit from present events. The miraculous transformations and spiritual powers move the noble and humble masses, and none are not moved to submission. The other spiritual powers do not have this.
For this reason, the spiritual power of transformation is placed first.
Question:
Since the bodies of heavenly beings have much fire and earth, their bodies have light and can ascend and move swiftly through the air;
Since the bodies of ghosts and spirits have much wind, their bodies are light and swift, unobstructed by anything;
Since the bodies of dragons have much water, they can produce water with their thoughts and also transform and move;
Since the bodies of humans have much earth and fire, their lightness and movement are less. How can they fly?
Answer:
Since the earth element in the human body has less lightness and movement, seeking to learn spiritual powers is like the heavens and spirits. What use is spiritual power for?
Just as the earth, although heavy, moves due to the power of water, in the same way, the power of the mind can lift the body.
It is like a monkey falling from a high place without injuring its body, while a person falling would be injured. This is because the power of a monkey's mind is light and strong, so it is unharmed;
Know that the power of the mind is strong.
Also, it is like a person who can float, who, although in deep water, does not sink. This is because the power of skillful means of the mind can support the body;
Therefore, know that although the human body is heavy, because the power of the mind is strong, the body flies through the sky.
Question:
If this is believable, how should one study it?
Answer:

If the practitioner abides in the fourth dhyÄna, relying on the four bases of supernatural power, single-mindedly concentrating the mind, observing the body as empty everywhere like the holes in a lotus root, taking the light and swift characteristics of the body, practicing them without ceasing, the body and mind merge like iron and fire merging, eliminating the coarse and heavy characteristics of the body, only having a light and swift body;
It combines with desire, diligence, thought, and auxiliary practices. Due to the power of good conduct such as desire, the body then follows like fire in iron, light and soft in use.
Moreover, the four great elements and derivative form of the form realm, being in this body and combining with the body, make the body light and convenient, able to go as one wishes.
It is like a person taking medicine, making the mind clear and the body light and convenient.
It is like the bright and pure four great elements and derivative form of the form realm, being in this body, making the eyes bright and pure.
It is like a person learning to jump, practicing and becoming more skilled than others, like a fledgling bird learning to fly, gradually flying farther and farther;
The spiritual power of the body is like this. When first attained, it may be one or two zhang, gradually able to fly farther.
This spiritual power of transformation has four kinds:

First, flying through the sky like a bird; second, being able to make the distant near; third, disappearing here and appearing there; fourth, being as swift as thought. In the time of a finger snap there are sixty thoughts, and in each thought one can traverse incalculably many koá¹­Ä«s of nayutas of buddha-realms, arriving wherever one wishes.

Using this spiritual power, one attains mastery over the body. One body can become many bodies, and many bodies can become one body. One can make the large small and the small large. One can be as heavy as Mount Sumeru and as light as a gossamer feather. One can do such things as one wishes.

Furthermore, the bodhisattva who has attained this spiritual power of the body can in a single thought traverse buddha-realms as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River. However, sentient beings see the bodhisattva arrive there, while the bodhisattva does not move from their original place. They expound the Dharma and teach and transform there, without neglecting this place.

Some devas and humans are attached to the inverted view of permanence, and can be liberated through spiritual powers. They manifest the burning of the trichiliocosm, while sentient beings see the trichiliocosm being burned and destroyed, yet the world is unharmed.
There are sentient beings whose minds give rise to arrogance. They manifest making a vajra-fist, and fire emerges from the vajra. Those who see it are terrified and submit in reverence.

There are people who delight in the body of a wheel-turning sage king. They manifest as a wheel-turning sage king and expound the Dharma for them. They may manifest as Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra, a demon king, a Å›rÄvaka, a pratyekabuddha, or the body of a buddha. They expound the Dharma according to the body that is delighted in.
The bodhisattva may also be sitting cross-legged in space, emitting various kinds of light from the four sides of his body and expounding the Dharma.

Sometimes, when sentient beings enjoy colorful adornments, he manifests the adornments of the seven treasures of the trichiliocosm, banners, flowers, canopies, and hundreds of kinds of music, and expounds the Dharma in the midst of them.
Sometimes he makes the trichiliocosm into a vast ocean, with blue and red lotus flowers covering the water's surface, and expounds the Dharma upon it.
Sometimes he sits on top of Mount Sumeru and expounds the Dharma with the sound of Brahma, which is heard throughout all countries.
Sometimes sentient beings do not see his form but only hear the sound of his Dharma.
Sometimes he takes on the body of a gandharva, and with the sound of music delights their minds, and then expounds the Dharma.
Sometimes he manifests as a dragon king with thunder, lightning, and hail, and expounds the Dharma.
In this way, through various causes and conditions and skillful means, he manifests spiritual transformations to attract sentient beings.
Question:
How is it that these spiritual transformations and manifestations of various things are not false?
Answer:

Practitioners first understand that all dharmas are false and deceptive, like illusions and transformations. It is like kneading clay to make whatever one desires. It is like a person with merit who can make it snow in summer, grow flowers in winter, and stop rivers from flowing. It is also like a sage who, in anger, can transform tigers, wolves, and lions into stone bodies. How much more so with the power of spiritual penetrations and samÄdhi, which do not transform things?
Furthermore, each thing has its own qi. Taking its divided form, the spiritual power expands it, while the rest disappears.
As the sÅ«tras say, there was a bhiká¹£u who, with the spiritual power of the mind attaining mastery, saw a large tree and wished to make it into earth, and it all became earth.
Why is this?
Because the tree has the element of earth.
If it is water, fire, or wind, it is the same.
If one makes gold, silver, and various precious things, one can make them all as one wishes.
Why is this?
Because the tree has the pure element.
Question:
If things transform like this, with transformation having no beginning or end, what is the matter?
Answer:
Some say that in empty space, the subtle dust particles created by the four great elements are caused by the power of the transforming mind to combine into a transformed person.

It is like when a person dies, they may be reborn in heaven or in hell, and due to the causes and conditions of their good and evil karma, the subtle dust particles combine to form a transformation, which is also like this. This is the characteristic of the spiritual power of transforming objects.

If a practitioner wishes to seek the divine ear, he should also take the fourth meditation as the basis, cultivate the four bases of supernatural powers as explained above, tame his mind, focus his thoughts on the sounds of the great assembly, grasp the characteristics of various sounds, and always imagine and think of the sounds he hears. If the mind is distracted, he should bring it back and always single-mindedly cultivate mindfulness. He will then obtain the pure form created by the four great elements of the form realm in his ears. This is called cultivating the divine ear.

With this divine ear, one hears the sounds of immeasurable lands in the ten directions, namely the sounds of gods, humans, dragons, asuras, gandharvas, kumbhÄá¹‡á¸as, mahoragas, and the sounds of animals, hungry ghosts, and the coarse and subtle sounds of the suffering and pain in the hells.

The bodhisattva's concentrated mind becomes increasingly profound, and he hears the sounds of the buddhas in the ten directions. He hears the Dharma from the buddhas but does not grasp at characteristics. He takes the Dharma as true and supreme, and relies on the profound meaning, not on words.
What is the profound meaning?
It is said to be knowing the emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness of all dharmas, and not giving rise to wrong views.
One does not attain the meaning within the meaning, and within the unattainable there is also no characteristic of attainment. This is relying on the profound meaning, not on language.
Furthermore, the practitioner relies on the definitive sÅ«tras, not on the non-definitive sÅ«tras.
As for the definitive sÅ«tras, if one is able to rely on the meaning, then all sÅ«tras are definitive, because the ultimate meaning of emptiness is beyond words.
Therefore, all sÅ«tras are definitive.
If one does not rely on the meaning, then for that person all sÅ«tras are not definitive.
Why is this?
Because lacking profound wisdom, one follows mere sounds.
The true nature of those sounds also enters the profound meaning, and both are beyond words. This is called distinguishing the definitive sÅ«tras from the non-definitive sÅ«tras.
Furthermore, the practitioner relies on wisdom and does not rely on consciousness.
Why is this?

The practitioner knows that the characteristics of consciousness arise from the combination of causes and conditions, have no inherent nature, are formless, unobstructing, invisible, unknowing, and unreal like an illusion.
Knowing the characteristics of consciousness in this way, consciousness becomes wisdom. Therefore, one relies on wisdom and does not rely on consciousness.

Although practitioners give rise to cognition, if cognition is not attached to cognition, they know cognition as characteristics. Cognition becomes the characteristics of cognition, and with these characteristics of cognition, they explain it to sentient beings.
Next, practitioners rely on the Dharma, not on the person.
Why is it so?

If there really were a person in the Buddha Dharma, there would be no pure attainment of liberation, but all dharmas are without self and without person. It is only in accordance with worldly convention that it is said there is a person and there is a self. For this reason, practitioners rely on the Dharma, not on the person.

What is called the Dharma is the nature of all dharmas. The nature of dharmas is the nature of non-arising. This nature of non-arising is ultimately empty. This ultimate emptiness is that which cannot be spoken.
Why is it so?

Because speech explains the Dharma, but within the Dharma there is no speech, and within speech there is no Dharma. Speech is the characteristic of speechlessness. All language is not the characteristic of language. For this reason, the sÅ«tras say, Without demonstration, without explanation, this is called the Buddha Dharma.

The practitioner hears the Dharma of the buddhas with the divine ear, and does not give rise to views of attachment to either people or dharmas. If one discriminates between two characteristics, it is not the Dharma of the buddhas. If there are no two characteristics, that is the Dharma of the buddhas.
The practitioner relies on the power of the divine ear to hear the profound Dharma and teach and transform sentient beings. This is called the supernormal knowledge of the divine ear.

If the practitioner wishes to attain the knowledge of others' minds, they first contemplate their own mind, grasping the characteristics of the arising, abiding, and ceasing of the mind, and also know the characteristics of the defilements and purity of the mind, the characteristics of concentration and distraction, and so forth. They further contemplate the defilements and purity, near and far, much and little, etc. of the objects of the mind.

Having grasped the characteristics of the internal and external mind, they take the mind with characteristics of desire, anger, arrogance, stinginess, jealousy, worry, fear, speech, sounds, various activities, and so forth as objects, and think like this:
The Buddha is like my mind, when it arises, abides, and ceases, so are they.
One knows the objects of one's own mind, and others are also like this.
My mind has such forms, appearances, and verbal expressions, and others are also like this.

Always cultivate and study the characteristics of the mind. Having practiced like this, one attains the supernormal knowledge of others' minds. At that time, one only observes the minds and mental factors of others, just as one with clear eyes observes fish in clear water, whether large or small, good or ugly, all are seen.
Although there is water covering them, due to the clarity of the water, it is not an obstruction.

The practitioner is like this. Because of the power of the supernormal knowledge of others' minds, although the minds of sentient beings are covered by the body, one can see them. Having attained the supernormal knowledge of others' minds, one may sometimes teach the Dharma to a large assembly, first knowing their minds, knowing what profound thoughts these sentient beings have, what practices they engage in, what causes and conditions they have, what characteristics they possess, and what things they delight in. Knowing one's own mind to be pure, one knows that the minds of sentient beings can also be pure.
It is like a clear mirror, in which whatever color there is, whether long or short, square or round, coarse or fine, appears just as it is, without increase or decrease.
Why is it so?
Because the mirror is pure.
Although the mirror does not discriminate, it manifests its characteristics.
The practitioner is also like this. Because his own mind is pure, the characteristics of all dharmas are always pure, without any fixed nature.

He knows all the mental activities of sentient beings. If there are many lustful people in the assembly, he knows their minds and teaches them the Dharma of leaving lust. The same is true for anger and delusion.
Why is it so?
The true nature of the mind is free from defilement, anger, and delusion.
If there are those seeking the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle in the assembly, he also knows their minds and teaches them the Dharma;
Although he teaches the Dharma, he knows that the nature of dharmas is also not small.
For those seeking the Pratyekabuddha path, he also knows their minds and teaches them the Dharma;
Although he teaches the Dharma, he knows that the nature of dharmas is also not middling.
If seeking the Great Vehicle, also know their minds and expound the Dharma for them;
Although expounding the Dharma, know that the nature of dharmas is also without greatness.
The practitioner is like this, equally following the minds of sentient beings and expounding the Dharma for them, also not discriminating the characteristics of the mind;
Although discriminating and expounding the Dharma of the three vehicles, not destroying the nature of dharmas;
Not destroying the nature of dharmas, therefore completely knowing the mental activities of all sentient beings.

Although using one's own mind to know the minds of others, there is no opposition or conformity between this and that mind, also knowing the continuity of the minds of all sentient beings like the flow of water.

Like knowing the nature of the mind, the nature of dharmas is also like this, using the knowledge of others' minds to know the minds of sentient beings and expound the Dharma for them, then it is not harmful, this is called the supernormal knowledge of knowing the minds of others.

If a practitioner wishes to know their past lives, they first become aware of their present experiences, their recent experiences, and gradually recall last night, yesterday, the day before, and so on, up to a month, from this year to childhood. It is like traveling to a destination and thinking back on the places they have passed through.

Having practiced in this way, due to the power of well-cultivated concentration, they recall their birth, being in the womb, knowing that they died in a certain place and were reborn in this womb, knowing one lifetime, two lifetimes, three lifetimes, up to a hundred lifetimes, a thousand lifetimes, ten thousand lifetimes, countless millions of lifetimes.
Using the knowledge of past lives, they know their own and others' experiences over eons as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, and they recall all of it.
Using the events of their past lives, they teach sentient beings, saying:
I was in such-and-such a place, with such-and-such a surname, such-and-such a birth, such-and-such a lifespan, and experienced such-and-such suffering and happiness.
They also tell of the events they experienced.

The practitioner, by the power of past life knowledge, knows the causes and conditions of the sins and merits of these sentient beings in their previous lives, namely the causes and conditions of planting the causes of Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and buddhas. He expounds the Dharma for them according to their causes and conditions.

Furthermore, by the power of the practitioner's knowledge of past lives, he knows for himself whether he has planted good roots towards the buddhas without dedicating them to supreme perfect enlightenment. He should now dedicate them to supreme perfect enlightenment.
The practitioner also knows that when dharmas in the past cease, they go nowhere. He knows that when dharmas in the future arise, they do not come from anywhere.
Although he knows that the past has no beginning, he does not give rise to the view of beginninglessness.
Although he contemplates the cessation and entry into nirvÄá¹‡a of sentient beings in the future, he also does not give rise to the extreme views.
When the practitioner recollects his past lives, he increases his good roots and eliminates the causes and conditions of sins from immeasurable lifetimes.
Why is it so?
He knows that all dharmas have no new characteristics and no old characteristics.

Having attained such wisdom, they contemplate all conditioned phenomena and the suffering and happiness experienced in the cycle of birth and death as if seeing a dream. For this reason, their minds do not become weary with the cycle of birth and death, and they give rise to a compassionate mind towards all beings. Knowing that all phenomena are created, they think:
Just as I have been wandering in the cycle of birth and death for countless eons, all of it is false and not real;
all beings who come and go in the cycle of birth and death are also like this.
If there were no four elements and four skandhas, that would be real, but the four elements and four skandhas are also ultimately unborn.

Furthermore, the practitioner recollects with the knowledge of past lives that they have been a wheel-turning sage king, and the pleasures they have experienced are impermanent and will perish. The pleasures of Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra are also impermanent and will perish. There are pure and adorned lands, and the supreme forms of bodhisattvas and buddhas, but even turning the wheel of the Dharma is impermanent, let alone other things.
Having contemplated in this way, the mind becomes disgusted with distance and separation.

The practitioner, relying on the knowledge of past lives, enters impermanence and emptiness, contemplating that all dharmas are empty and impermanent, yet sentient beings are attached due to delusion.
For the sake of these sentient beings, one gives rise to the mind of compassion. Cultivating this mind of compassion, one gradually attains the accomplishment of great compassion.
Having attained great compassion, the Buddhas of the ten directions think of this bodhisattva and praise his virtues. This is called the supernormal knowledge of past lives.
If the practitioner wishes to seek the divine eye, he should first take the characteristics of bright light, such as the light of lamps, pearls, the sun, moon, stars, etc.
Having taken these bright characteristics, if it is daytime, then close the eyes, and at night, without being present, contemplate the bright characteristics as if seen by the eyes.
Always cultivate bright mindfulness, focusing the mind on the bright and not allowing other thoughts. If it goes away, bring it back and focus the mind in one place.

At that time, the pure form created by the four great elements of the form realm is in this eye, which is called the heavenly eye. Because it is created by the four great elements of the heavens, it is called the heavenly eye. Also, because it is the pure eye of the sages and saints, it is called the heavenly eye.

After the practitioner has attained this heavenly eye, the mountains, trees, Iron Encircling Mountains, Mount Sumeru, and all lands have no obstruction at all. With this unobstructed eye, he can see the innumerable and incalculable buddhas of the ten directions and their adorned lands.
At that time, the practitioner can know that all buddhas are one buddha, and also see one buddha as all buddhas, because the nature of dharmas is indestructible.
Just as he sees the characteristics of the buddhas, he also sees the characteristics of his own body in the same way.
Because the characteristics of his own body are pure, the characteristics of all dharmas are also like this.
Just as he sees the purity of the buddhas,
his disciples are also like this, without any dualistic characteristics.

And the sentient beings in the immeasurable lands of the ten directions, whether in the hells, animal realm, hungry ghost realm, human realm, or heavenly realm, except for those in the formless realm, all see their good and bad rebirths, and know the causes and effects of the karma of the sentient beings of the six paths in the ten directions:

These sentient beings, due to the causes and conditions of good karma, are reborn among humans and gods. These sentient beings, due to the causes and conditions of unwholesome karma, are reborn in the three evil destinies.

Although the practitioner, through the power of wisdom obtained from the heavenly eye, sees sentient beings, he does not give rise to the notion of sentient beings, because all dharmas are devoid of the notion of sentient beings;
Although he sees the continuity of karma and its effects, he also enters into the state where all dharmas are devoid of karma and its effects.
Although he sees all forms with the heavenly eye, due to the power of wisdom, he also does not grasp the characteristics of forms, because all forms are ultimately empty.
Furthermore, whether obstructed or unobstructed, near or far, above or below, there is nothing that is not seen.
